title: Lamentations Quiz - Complete Book
description: Test your comprehensive knowledge of the entire book of Lamentations with 25 questions covering key events, people, and teachings from all 5 chapters.

questions.question: In Lamentations 1:1, how is the city described?
questions.explanation: The city is described as sitting solitary, that was full of people, and like a widow.

questions.question: According to Lamentations 1:5, why has the LORD afflicted the city?
options: For the multitude of her transgressions
questions.correctAnswer: For the multitude of her transgressions
questions.explanation: The LORD has afflicted her for the multitude of her transgressions as stated in the verse.

questions.question: What is the condition of Judah as described in Lamentations 1:3?
options: Gone into captivity because of affliction
questions.correctAnswer: Gone into captivity because of affliction
questions.explanation: Judah is said to have gone into captivity due to affliction and great servitude.

questions.question: In Lamentations 1:9, what does the city remember not, which contributed to her downfall?
questions.explanation: The city forgets her last end, leading to her coming down wonderfully without a comforter.

questions.question: Who are described as having dealt treacherously with the city in Lamentations 1:2?
questions.explanation: The text says all her friends dealt treacherously with her and became her enemies.

questions.question: What is the state of the gates of Zion according to Lamentations 1:4?
questions.explanation: The verse clearly states that all her gates are desolate due to mourning.

questions.question: According to Lamentations 2:1, what has the Lord done to the daughter of Zion?
options: Covered her with a cloud in his anger
questions.correctAnswer: Covered her with a cloud in his anger
questions.explanation: The Lord covered the daughter of Zion with a cloud in his anger and cast down the beauty of Israel.

questions.question: What happened to the king and princes of the daughter of Zion in Lamentations 2:9?
options: They were protected by the Lord
questions.explanation: The verse explains that her king and princes are among the Gentiles.

questions.question: In Lamentations 2:19, what is the instruction given to cry out in the night?
options: Pour out thy heart like water before the Lord
questions.correctAnswer: Pour out thy heart like water before the Lord
questions.explanation: The verse instructs to arise, cry out in the night, and pour out the heart like water before the Lord.

questions.question: Who is the speaker in Lamentations 3:1?
options: The man that hath seen affliction by the rod of his wrath
questions.correctAnswer: The man that hath seen affliction by the rod of his wrath
questions.explanation: The speaker identifies himself as the man who has experienced affliction by God's rod of wrath.

questions.question: What does Lamentations 3:22 say about the LORD's mercies?
options: They are few and far between
questions.explanation: The verse explains that the LORD's mercies are new every morning and His compassions fail not.

questions.question: According to Lamentations 3:24, what does the LORD represent to the speaker's soul?
questions.explanation: The speaker says the LORD is his portion and therefore he will hope in Him.

questions.question: What is the attitude toward suffering expressed in Lamentations 3:27?
options: It is good for a man to bear the yoke in his youth
Suffering should be avoided at all costs
Suffering is a sign of failure
Youth should be free from burdens
questions.correctAnswer: It is good for a man to bear the yoke in his youth
questions.explanation: The verse expresses that bearing suffering (the yoke) in youth is beneficial.

questions.question: Which metaphor is used in Lamentations 3:10 to describe the Lord's treatment of the speaker?
options: As a bear lying in wait and a lion in secret places
As a shepherd guiding his sheep
questions.correctAnswer: As a bear lying in wait and a lion in secret places
questions.explanation: The Lord is compared to a bear and lion attacking unexpectedly.

questions.question: In Lamentations 3:31, what does the Lord not do?
questions.explanation: The verse states that the Lord will not cast off forever.

questions.question: According to Lamentations 4:1, what has happened to the gold and the most fine gold?
options: The gold is become dim and the fine gold changed
The gold is increased in value
questions.correctAnswer: The gold is become dim and the fine gold changed
questions.explanation: The verse laments that the gold has lost its luster and quality.

questions.question: What theme is most prominent throughout the book of Lamentations?
options: Sorrow and mourning over Jerusalem's destruction
questions.correctAnswer: Sorrow and mourning over Jerusalem's destruction
questions.explanation: Lamentations centers on grief over Jerusalem's ruin and God's judgment.

questions.question: In Lamentations 2:20, what disturbing question is asked about the women and children?
options: Shall the women eat their fruit and children of a span long?
Are the women joyful and the children strong?
Will the women lead the army?
Are the children safe in the sanctuary?
questions.correctAnswer: Shall the women eat their fruit and children of a span long?
questions.explanation: The verse questions whether women will eat their own children due to famine and siege.

questions.question: What does Lamentations 3:40 encourage people to do?
options: Search and try their ways, and turn again to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Search and try their ways, and turn again to the LORD
questions.explanation: The verse calls for self-examination and repentance.

questions.question: According to Lamentations 1:17, what is Jerusalem compared to among her adversaries?
questions.explanation: Jerusalem is likened to a menstruous woman among her enemies, indicating impurity and isolation.

questions.question: What event is Lamentations primarily lamenting?
options: The destruction of Jerusalem and the Temple
questions.correctAnswer: The destruction of Jerusalem and the Temple
questions.explanation: The book mourns the devastation caused by Babylon's siege and destruction.

questions.question: In Lamentations 2:14, what did the prophets fail to do?
options: Discover the iniquity to turn away captivity
questions.correctAnswer: Discover the iniquity to turn away captivity
questions.explanation: The prophets saw vain things and did not reveal the sin that led to captivity.

questions.question: According to Lamentations 3:32, how does the Lord respond to grief?
options: He has compassion according to the multitude of his mercies
questions.correctAnswer: He has compassion according to the multitude of his mercies
questions.explanation: Though He causes grief, the Lord shows compassion abundantly.

questions.question: Lamentations 1:12 asks if it is nothing to those who pass by to behold what?
options: If there be any sorrow like unto my sorrow
questions.correctAnswer: If there be any sorrow like unto my sorrow
questions.explanation: The verse asks if passersby see any sorrow like the speaker's sorrow caused by the LORD's fierce anger.

questions.question: In Lamentations 2:22, what has the enemy consumed?
options: Those that have been swaddled and brought up
questions.correctAnswer: Those that have been swaddled and brought up
questions.explanation: The enemy has consumed the infants and children tenderly cared for.

questions.question: In Lamentations 3:15, the speaker says he is filled with what?
questions.explanation: The speaker laments being filled with bitterness and wormwood, a symbol of sorrow.

questions.question: What is the significance of 'the yoke' in Lamentations 1:14?
options: It symbolizes the burden of transgressions
It is a symbol of victory
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the burden of transgressions
questions.explanation: The yoke of transgressions is bound on the neck, indicating captivity and burden.

questions.question: According to Lamentations 1:19, who gave up the ghost in the city?
questions.explanation: The priests and elders died while seeking food to relieve their souls.

questions.question: Which chapter contains the famous passage about the LORDâ€™s mercies being new every morning?
questions.explanation: The passage about the LORD's mercies being new every morning is found in Chapter 3.

questions.question: What does Lamentations 2:7 say the Lord has done to his altar and sanctuary?
options: He hath cast off his altar and abhorred his sanctuary
He has blessed and protected them
questions.correctAnswer: He hath cast off his altar and abhorred his sanctuary
questions.explanation: The Lord rejected his altar and sanctuary, allowing enemies to invade.

questions.question: In Lamentations 3:28, what does the person do because he has borne the yoke?
options: He sitteth alone and keepeth silence
questions.correctAnswer: He sitteth alone and keepeth silence
questions.explanation: Because he has borne the yoke, he sits alone in silence.

questions.question: What imagery is used in Lamentations 1:6 to describe the princes of the city?
options: Like harts that find no pasture
questions.correctAnswer: Like harts that find no pasture
questions.explanation: The princes are compared to deer that find no pasture and are without strength.

questions.question: What is the 'net for my feet' mentioned in Lamentations 1:13 referring to?
options: A trap set by God leading to desolation
questions.correctAnswer: A trap set by God leading to desolation
questions.explanation: The net symbolizes God's judgment that ensnares the speaker causing desolation.

questions.question: According to Lamentations 4:4, what has happened to the precious sons of Zion compared to gold?
options: Their brightness is as the brightness of the sun
They are as dim as old gold
questions.correctAnswer: Their brightness is as the brightness of the sun
questions.explanation: The precious sons are described as bright as the sun but now are darkened by affliction.

questions.question: True or False: According to Lamentations 3:33, God afflicts people willingly and to cause grief.
questions.explanation: The verse states God does not afflict willingly nor grieve the children of men.

questions.question: True or False: Lamentations 2:5 describes the LORD as swallowing up Israel and all her palaces.
questions.explanation: The LORD is described as an enemy swallowing up Israel and her palaces.

questions.question: True or False: According to Lamentations 1:11, the people are well-fed and joyful.
questions.explanation: The people sigh and seek bread, having given pleasant things for meat to relieve the soul.

questions.question: True or False: Lamentations 3:31 says the Lord will cast off his people forever.
questions.explanation: It explicitly states the Lord will not cast off forever.

questions.question: True or False: Lamentations 1:18 expresses that the LORD is righteous despite the speaker's rebellion.
questions.explanation: The verse declares the LORD is righteous because the speaker has rebelled.

questions.question: True or False: Lamentations 2:10 describes the elders and virgins of Zion as joyful and singing.
questions.explanation: They sit on the ground in silence, wearing sackcloth, mourning.

questions.question: True or False: Lamentations 3 teaches that it is good for a man to quietly wait for the salvation of the LORD.
questions.explanation: The text affirms it is good to hope and quietly wait for God's salvation.

questions.question: True or False: Lamentations 4:5 mentions that the tongue of the nursing child cleaveth to the roof of the mouth for thirst.
questions.explanation: This verse describes the dire famine affecting even nursing children.

questions.question: Complete this verse: 'The LORD is my portion, saith my soul; therefore will I ______ in him.'
questions.explanation: The verse expresses confidence and hope in the LORD as one's portion.

questions.question: Complete this verse: 'For he doth not afflict willingly nor grieve the ______ of men.'
questions.explanation: God does not willingly afflict or grieve the children of men.

questions.question: Complete this verse: 'Let us search and try our ways, and turn again to the ______.'
questions.explanation: The verse calls for repentance and turning back to the LORD.
